commander.name: Marie-Pierre Kœnig
commander.previous_service: Commanded Free French forces in Eritrea campaign

Canon de 75mm Mle 1897.note: 30 used in anti-tank role by May 1942

Bofors 40mm.note: Increased to 12 by May 1942, with 6 additional British-manned

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations. Primary logistics through British supply chain from Tobruk (280km). Brigade building up defensive stores at Bir Hakeim position throughout Q1 1942. Three months of preparation time from February occupation to May battle. Mixed French and British equipment creates maintenance challenges.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Rocky desert with wadis - Bir Hakeim position sits on low rocky plateau

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 1er Régiment d'Artillerie de la France Libre
subordinate_units.composition: 48x 75mm field guns, anti-tank company, anti-aircraft company

tactical_doctrine.role: Independent defensive brigade under British XXX Corps command. Specialized in desert warfare with strong defensive capabilities. Multi-national composition (French, Spanish Republicans, colonial troops from Africa and Pacific).
special_capabilities: Desert warfare experience from Syrian and Eritrean campaigns
Combined arms coordination with limited resources
Multi-national integration (French Foreign Legion includes Spanish Republicans)
tactical_innovations: Adaptation of limited French equipment with British supply system
Integration of colonial troops from Chad, Congo, and Pacific islands
Defensive box tactics learned from British forces
known_issues: Mixed French and British equipment complicates logistics
Limited heavy weapons compared to German/Italian opponents
Reliance on British supply chain creates dependencies
Outdated French 75mm guns used in dual anti-tank/field artillery role
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Three months of preparation at Bir Hakeim position (Feb-May 1942). Extensive minefield laying, strongpoint construction, and water storage. Troops experienced from Syrian campaign and adaptation to British desert warfare doctrine.

scenario_suitability: Combined Free French and British forces
special_rules: Stubborn Defense: Free French units gain +1 morale in defensive positions
Multi-national Force: Brigade includes French, Spanish, African, and Pacific personnel
Limited Heavy Weapons: Restricted access to armor and heavy artillery
British Supply: Operates on British logistics

exact_equipment_counts_q1.reason: Most detailed equipment data is from Bir Hakeim battle (May-June 1942, Q2). Q1 data extrapolated from Q2 known values, assuming build-up phase.
sources_checked: Multiple web searches for Q1-specific data
exact_equipment_counts_q1.estimate_method: Used confirmed Q2 equipment counts (48x 75mm, 14x 47mm at Bir Hakeim in May) and reduced by ~15% to estimate Q1 build-up phase. Artillery reduced from 54 to 48 guns, anti-tank from 14 to 12 (47mm), 18 to 4 (25mm).
exact_equipment_counts_q1.mitigation: Consult French military archives (Service Historique de la Défense) or Nafziger Collection for January-March 1942 specific TO&E documents

complete_officer_roster.reason: Only brigade commander (Koenig), Chief of Staff (Masson), and battalion commanders confirmed. Company-level officers not documented in available sources.
complete_officer_roster.mitigation: Access Free French personnel records at Service Historique de la Défense or Mémorial de la France Libre

precise_vehicle_models.reason: Vehicle types inferred from general Free French equipment patterns and British supply. Specific model numbers not confirmed for Q1 1942.
precise_vehicle_models.estimate_method: Used known French vehicle types (Laffly, Renault) combined with British supply vehicles (Bedford, Dodge) typical of 1942 British logistics support
precise_vehicle_models.mitigation: Research British XXX Corps supply records or Free French logistics documents at UK National Archives or French archives
